briefing.opening: Good morning/afternoon. We will now begin the climate briefing for February 24, 2026.

sections.title: ğŸ”´ Climate Crisis Warning Signals: Major International and Domestic Concerns
sections.content: Today, severe warning bells are ringing globally due to climate change. Climate change is exacerbating inflation, and extreme co-occurring phenomena have been observed, such as atmospheric rivers causing complex floods in Western North America [60, 71]. It has been pointed out that Europe's climate adaptation efforts remain insufficient and fragmented, and concerns have also been raised that global warming is increasing the risk of heatwaves for major cycling races like the Tour de France, potentially leading to schedule readjustments [73, 74, 81, 92]. Furthermore, the U.S. Supreme Court has agreed to hear arguments from oil companies seeking to block climate change lawsuits, drawing attention to the outcome of the legal battle [66, 68, 76]. Domestically, news that 'climate response' has been excluded from the International Energy Agency (IEA)'s priority list has emerged, raising concerns about a potential retreat in climate response efforts [3].

sections.title: ğŸ‡°ğŸ‡· Domestic Efforts Towards Carbon Neutrality and Practical Challenges
sections.content: Various local governments and companies in Korea are making diverse efforts to achieve carbon neutrality goals. Chungnam Province is accelerating the realization of carbon neutrality by 2045, strengthening cooperation through meetings of provincial and municipal/county environmental department heads, and Gwangmyeong City has embarked on developing a smart carbon-neutral city model [13, 15, 18, 23, 28, 30, 31, 32]. Furthermore, Hyundai Department Store is participating in the government's Carbon Neutrality Point System, encouraging customers' eco-friendly activities, and Yangpyeong County is recruiting participants for the Carbon Neutrality Point System through reduced mileage, promoting citizen participation [20, 24, 27, 34]. However, the observation that the spread of green building in Chungnam is concentrated solely in the public sector, and the controversy over the effectiveness of the Carbon Neutrality Energy Point System due to its low participation rate (less than 5%) indicate an urgent need for private sector expansion and institutional improvement of carbon neutrality policies [6, 11].

sections.title: ğŸŒ± Accelerating Renewable Energy Transition and Challenges to Address
sections.content: Domestic infrastructure development and cooperation for renewable energy expansion are actively underway. The Korea National Railway Authority is collaborating with Hanwha Q CELLS to promote renewable energy expansion in the railway sector, thereby expanding the 'railway-type new and renewable energy' domain [35, 41, 43, 49, 53, 54, 58]. The Saemangeum Development and Investment Agency is also joining forces to spread renewable energy in the Jeonbuk region, establishing itself as a hub for demonstration and dissemination, and the 'Power System Innovation Measures TF' has been launched to prepare for the 100GW era of renewable energy [36, 39, 44, 45, 46]. Meanwhile, the Korea Energy Agency has launched full-cycle support for solar power by operating a registration system for Renewable Energy Service Companies (ReSCO) [40, 42, 50, 51, 55, 56]. However, issues of public anxiety due to the installation of wind and solar power generation facilities near residential areas and roads, and the surge in imports of Chinese products due to solar power expansion policies remain important challenges to be addressed in the renewable energy transition process [38, 48].

sections.title: ğŸ“° Enhancing Understanding of Climate Change and Advancements in Science and Technology
sections.content: Efforts to enhance public understanding of climate change and develop response technologies are continuing both domestically and internationally. Domestically, the Cheongju Land Climate Change Experience Center, which has undergone renovation, is preparing for its reopening, and Jeonju City plans to announce and expand standard educational materials for life-cycle-based carbon neutrality citizen education [1, 2, 19, 29]. Internationally, technologies utilizing lasers and drones to assess global forest health and track climate change are being supported, and a joint research team from KAIST and Korea University has announced positive progress in climate technology by developing a technology to address the shortened lifespan and fire risk of lithium-metal batteries [59, 63]. Furthermore, research on how climate change has shaped evolution and South Africa's advocacy for maintaining its carbon tax are fostering in-depth discussions on the complexity of climate change and its response measures [80, 82, 84].

briefing.closing: As we have seen in today's briefing, climate change is a global challenge, requiring both international cooperation and practical domestic efforts simultaneously. This concludes today's climate briefing.

articles.original_title: â€˜ìˆ˜ëª… ë‹¨ì¶•Â·í™”ì¬ ìœ„í—˜â€™ ë‚œì œ í•´ê²°â€¦ê¿ˆì˜ ë°°í„°ë¦¬ ê¸°ìˆ  ê°œë°œ
articles.description: A joint research team from KAIST and Korea University has developed a technology to address the challenges of shortened lifespan and fire risk in lithium-metal batteries. With the advent of the electric vehicle era, research into batteries that can travel farther and last longer has intensified. Lithium-metal batteries are gaining attention as a next-generation technology to overcome the capacity limitations of existing lithium-ion batteries. However, lithium-metal batteries face issues such as the formation of needle-shaped dendrites during charging, leading to reduced lifespan and fire hazards.

summary.phenomenon: A joint research team from KAIST and Korea University has developed a technology to resolve the critical issues of shortened lifespan and fire risk in lithium-metal batteries.
summary.cause: The advent of the electric vehicle era has spurred research into next-generation battery technologies that surpass the capacity limitations of existing lithium-ion batteries. Lithium-metal batteries, while promising, have faced challenges due to the formation of needle-shaped 'dendrites' during charging, which causes shortened lifespan and fire hazards.
